{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3392138,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T12:20:27.796Z","cooked":"

Our team is looking to get two powerful PCs for our CAD team that works with SolidWorks. We currently have three options under consideration:

  1. A gaming PC with a GeForce GPU, such as the 4060Ti 12GB.
  2. A prebuilt PC with a GPU that is “verified” by SolidWorks: Intel Core™ i7-13700, 64GB RAM, 1TB SSD, NVIDIA Quadro T1000.
  3. Instead of buying two PCs, invest in one very powerful PC with the combined budget of the two PCs, based on recommendations from third-party sources like Puget Systems: Puget Systems SolidWorks Hardware Recommendations.

I have concerns that the second option includes a relatively weak and older GPU, which might pose performance issues.

If we decide to go with the first option, what kind of CPU should we be looking for? Does clock speed matter more than core count for SolidWorks? Should we consider an AMD CPU or stick with Intel?

Additionally, how much RAM should the PC have, and is the speed of the RAM crucial?

We’re aiming for a budget-friendly solution. Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-26T12:20:27.796Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6667,"reads":357,"readers_count":356,"score":33376.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Yoav","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pugetsystems.com/solutions/cad-workstations/solidworks/hardware-recommendations/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Hardware Recommendations for SOLIDWORKS | Puget Systems","clicks":92}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/1","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3392142,"name":"Jonathan shani","username":"Jonathanshani","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/bcef8e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T12:55:12.763Z","cooked":"

Hi
My personal computer which was built for music production has roughly the specs you described in section 2

I7-12700 cpu
64gb of ram
1tb ssd and 4tb SATA III drive.
And a relatively basic Nvidia Quadro p2000 gpu

SolidWorks works like a charm on it and loads FRC related assemblies quickly. It definitely wasn’t cheap, but it seems from your description that you have the budget for something like that.

FRC robots, while not being able to run smoothly on any computer, still aren’t that heavy the part count is relatively small and we don’t use complex surfaces usually. Even the computers at our lab, with an I5 processor and 16gb of ram I think, can manage them ok.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-26T12:55:52.707Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":39,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":305.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Jonathan shani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36940,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392148,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T14:23:30.394Z","cooked":"

For the majority of the time, Solidworks is single-threaded and CPU limited. Your priorities for a SW machine should be clock speed, RAM, GPU, and then core count in that order.

If you’re loading a lot of big assemblies, that can eat away at your RAM. 32GB should be plenty. Faster RAM may help a bit, but again the bottleneck is usually processor speed.

Intel vs AMD, I don’t think there’s a big difference these days. Whichever you can get a better price on. I would recommend sticking with Nvidia graphics cards though, I’ve heard bad things about AMD’s compatibility with SW.

All the “verified” GPU gets you is RealView and it turns off the popup on startup saying “your graphics card may not be supported”. A gaming graphics card with similar specs will be a lot cheaper and will perform just as well. The workstation GPUs are really for companies that need the 100% guaranteed compatibility, where losing a day messing with settings costs you more than the difference in GPU prices.

Graphics RAM is important if you’re viewing complicated assemblies. Especially so if you have multiple displays. A weaker GPU with lots of RAM may perform better than a stronger one with the minimum RAM. Graphics RAM is also important for rendering, if that’s something that matters to you.

This of course depends on your team, how many students you have, etc. But overall, my suggestion would be rather than buying two really strong computers, you look into buying three or four medium-strength computers. My team was donated two powerful workstation computers a few years ago (Ryzen 3700X, Quadro RTX 4000). We still use them, but for CAD we often find ourselves working in the school’s computer lab instead using much weaker computers (Intel i3 and i5, may even be integrated graphics) because it means we can have our whole CAD team working in parallel in the same room.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-26T14:23:30.394Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":279,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":1574.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Ari Meles-Braverman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/3","custom_user_title":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392216,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-26T19:00:40.492Z","cooked":"

Thank you for the info and the help!

I have in mind this PC:

  • CPU: Intel i7-12700
  • GPU: RTX 3050 8GB
  • RAM: 32GB DDR4
  • Storage: 1TB M.2 NVME SSD
  • Cooling: 240mm AIO for the CPU

Will this setup be able to handle pretty much any robot assembly I throw at it? Any additional tips or considerations would be greatly appreciated!

Are you looking specifically for a desktop or a laptop

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-26T19:23:02.123Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":208,"readers_count":207,"score":66.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Pizzatc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54022,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2659"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/5","custom_user_title":"2659","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392337,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T07:00:34.765Z","cooked":"

A desktop

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T07:00:34.765Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":61.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Yoav","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54022,"username":"Pizzatc","name":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/6","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392343,"name":"Samir Chaman Serna","username":"Samir003","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/samir003/{size}/156937_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T08:40:28.646Z","cooked":"

For what I recall, SolidWorks is extremely dependent on the CPU, basically all the modeling aspect in this program is single core.

The GPU only enters the game when you start adding a lot of parts in an assembly and/or when you have a very complex part with a lot of curved surfaces.

If you plan to do simulations, you will need as many cores in your CPU and RAM as you can afford.

For rendering, you can use PhotoView 360 that only uses CPU and as many cores as you cand throw at it, or use Visualize, that needs a pretty betty GPU.

So… if these computers are meant to be used exclusively for SolidWorks I will recommend the following:

  • Thes fastest single core CPU you can get.

  • The fastest STABLE RAM compatible with your CPU.

  • A minimum of 16GB of RAM, preferably 32 or more.

  • A fast SSD.

  • If it enters in your budget, get a certificate GPU like RTX a2000 (they have a huge difference in performance only for the type of drivers they use).

Also, usually more people designing would get you faster a cad model of a robot than a super-fast and expensive PC, so try to prioritize that.

Finally, in my experience you can get a ton of work done in SolidWorks with almost any modern PC, an optimized Windows installation and good CADing practices.

All the following robots were designed in a laptop with an i3 6th gen. 8gb of RAM and an HDD. It wasn't fun but it was doable.
  • Team México Robot FGC 2019
  • Cerbotic 15600 FTC 2019 - 2020 (Monty)
  • Not the 15600 Robot FTC 2021
  • FRC Team 4400 2020/2021 Robot - 1-E-2 Reloaded
  • FRC Team 4400 2022 Robot - Nick
    (I think that, with the last one, I updated to 16GB of RAM and a SATA SSD)
","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T08:40:28.646Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":34,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":225.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Samir Chaman Serna","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/team-mexico-robot-fgc-2019-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":7},{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/frc-team-4400-2022-robot-nick-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":7},{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/frc-team-4400-2020-2021-robot-1-e-2-reloaded-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2},{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/cerbotic-15600-ftc-2019-2020-monty-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2},{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/not-the-15600-robot-ftc-2021-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43248,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor - A bit of everything."},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor - A bit of everything.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392350,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T11:16:23.042Z","cooked":"
Samir003:

Finally, in my experience you can get a ton of work done in SolidWorks with almost any modern PC, an optimized Windows installation and good CADing practices.

Yes, this. I’ve been running SolidWorks for FRC and for my mechanical design consulting job for years on laptops with integrated graphics and 8-16gb of ram. Just get the best CPU in your price range and get as many people in CAD as possible.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T11:16:23.042Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":99.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/8","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392359,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T12:31:18.002Z","cooked":"

I’m on a relatively cheap gaming laptop I selected more for the fact that it was the fastest Ryzen 7 I could get for my budget and that I could upgrade and repair it myself than anything else, but Solidworks compatibility was very much considered in my choice (which is why I have a 3060, and by now have upgraded to 32gb ram/3tb ssd storage)
Adding on to the verified graphics card, it may make your time running Solidworks Visualize easier… although that may have just been a whole lotta trouble on my end setting up between the integrated and dedicated graphics cards I have.

Personally I’d recommend a bunch of older Dell business machines, 5000 series Latitudes are great and cheap as heck. They run Solidworks really well and for the budget you’re talking about with 2 relatively powerful brand new PCs, you should be able to get 5-10 of these Dell laptops.

If you need desktops, don’t get prebuilt machines, either build yourself or ask a local pc repair guy to build it - it’ll be cheaper and higher quality anyway.

I really like AMD cpus because of the cheaper cores and pretty much identical single thread speed as Intel, but other than the whole P-core/E-core thing, there’s no real difference.

Don’t put spinners in the machine, they’re more trouble than they’re worth now. SSDs are so cheap.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T12:31:18.002Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":93.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/9","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392413,"name":"Pizzatc","username":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T16:11:03.330Z","cooked":"

https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/desktop-computers/inspiron-desktop/spd/inspiron-3020-desktop/useithbts3020gmvn

image2713×1517 409 KB

This desktop right here which I just looked up is honestly a really good deal and has specs really close to my laptop which runs Solidworks like butter.

Specs are

Intel i7 13th Gen
1TB SSD
16GB
Nividia 3050

For 950$, IMO thats a really good deal and you could buy two of them for 2000$ dollars and I bet if you contact Dell and explain you’re a school you can get a discount.

All of that should be good enough for what FRC does.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T16:12:46.020Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":98.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Pizzatc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/desktop-computers/inspiron-desktop/spd/inspiron-3020-desktop/useithbts3020gmvn","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":28},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/e/a/eae3c52e3fdf64a7440453d50745ce64e5b12717.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57373,"username":"Yoav-R","name":"Yoav","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54022,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2659"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/10","custom_user_title":"2659","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392418,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T16:17:55.101Z","cooked":"

Avoid Dell prebuilt desktops. The build quality is awful, the cooling sucks (this is a massive problem for any modern processor, but especially Intels), and the case is so fundamentally flawed that you need to replace the case to get decent cooling. However replacing the case may require a new motherboard, I can’t remember if Dell is in the weird motherboard shape camp or not.

I’m not even including the Dell preinstalled bloatware junk that pretty much forces a clean Windows reinstall to get rid of a lot of the time.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T16:19:08.824Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":42.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54022,"username":"Pizzatc","name":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/11","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392421,"name":"Pizzatc","username":"Pizzatc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pizzatc/{size}/207342_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T16:25:54.541Z","cooked":"

Cannot confirm that on their desktops. But I’ve used one of their XPS laptops and I’ve had nothing but a great experience on it, I’ve never had it get that hot even while really pushing it. As for the software it can be uninstalled, yes it’s annoying but it is useable.

Also while I support people buying and modifying desktops, schools(at least from my experience) do not like that idea because they want something with a warranty and from a company they know.

Their XPS lineup is their high end, they may put some effort into that and their business machines because that’s where their money comes from, but I’ve had nothing but trouble come from the various Inspiron (in particular) machines I’ve worked on.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T17:19:07.515Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":30.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Pizzatc","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29971,"username":"gellnick","name":"Nyx","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54022,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2659"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/14","custom_user_title":"2659","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392471,"name":"Joey Tidrow","username":"Arrowmag","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arrowmag/{size}/233870_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T18:11:19.230Z","cooked":"

I thought to throw my idea for this. Last year we made two new Cad systems for solid works but I am not going to recommend what we did due to the prices going substantly up on some of the components and are no longer worth it. Below is a list that I made in a few minutes and is not perfect but a good place to start.

https://pcpartpicker.com/list/P4kpwg

CPU: AMD 7600 - Good processor with high boost clocks, a lot of cache, and AM5 for easy upgrading later.

Ram: 32gb DDR5-6000 CL38 - Good Ram and more future proof than DDR4

GPU: 3060 12gb - A lot of Vram for working with larger assemblies and can be 20-40% faster than 3050

Storage: 1Tb NVMe SSD - Good Fast SSD that runs at PCIe 4.0 speeds

MotherBoard: MSI PRO B650M - Good AM5 Motherboard

PSU: 600w + from any good brand.

Case: Anything that has ok airflow

CPU Cooler: Stock cooler can work if needed but even the $17 USD cooler is a good upgrade. Most other air coolers with heat pipes should be fine, no need for a big expensive AIO.

Total: $900 USD

This list should not be taken by heart and should be changed based on local prices, availability, and user preferences.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T18:11:19.230Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":17,"reads":101,"readers_count":100,"score":105.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Joey Tidrow","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://pcpartpicker.com/list/P4kpwg","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":26}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59796,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1646M 2851A "},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/15","custom_user_title":"1646M 2851A ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392504,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T19:45:30.488Z","cooked":"

If you can find a screaming deal (say…free in a dumpster with only year old hardware) it’s worth it to gut the thing for the CPU, GPU, and RAM. Case is weird, motherboard is weird, and even the PSUs are weird. The stock machines are mostly fine until you need to upgrade, or the airflow becomes a problem.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T19:45:30.488Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":27.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29971,"username":"gellnick","name":"Nyx","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/16","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392510,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T20:01:11.791Z","cooked":"

Free in a dumpster implies something died, I would assume.
Still good to gut it for CPU/GPU/RAM/storage (depending what’s in there).
The problem with most of these prebuilts is that the case is designed for aesthetics not airflow, so they’re not great from the start.

gellnick:

Free in a dumpster implies something died, I would assume.

You need to find some better dumpsters
Some IT departments can be a bit more wasteful than others, no harm in asking around.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T20:04:15.448Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/18","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392514,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T20:05:36.456Z","cooked":"

It also helps that the dumpsters near me usually have very heavy things dumped on top of any electronics that might happen to be in there.
I am attempting to get in contact with a couple IT departments to get a couple older machines though. Should be good fun negotiating.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2024-05-27T20:05:36.456Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466915,"topic_slug":"advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":26760,"username":"troy_dietz","name":"Troy Dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/advice-needed-for-pc-selection-for-solidworks/466915/19","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3392526,"name":"Ankur Raghavan","username":"Ankur-Raghavan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ankur-raghavan/{size}/207141_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-27T21:02:36.660Z","cooked":"
troy_dietz:

Some IT departments can be a bit more wasteful than others

Can confirm that IT departments get rid of desktops all the time. We usually get rid of them after their 5 year warranty, and the team has been able to get a few of them as needed. But we didn’t get permission to remove the school image from them, so it takes a bit to sign in. We’ll need more desk space before adding any more computers.

We found CAD works best at home as many of the members interested in CAD are also interested in building stuff. We use OnShape so it’s easier on the computers (but most kids have gaming computers anyways).
